case_name: Dr. Jiwan Lal and others v. Brij Mohan Mehra

facts.text: Appeal filed as C.A. No. 1100 of 1967 by certificate from Punjab High Court judgment dated January 25, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 1100 of 1967. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and decree dated January 25, 1966 of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 362 of 1964.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab and Haryana delivered judgment and decree dated January 25, 1966 reversing Subordinate Judge's decree.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana, dated January 25, 1966. The High Court reversed the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Amritsar, dated August 17, 1964.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Amritsar decreed plaintiffs' suit for possession by specific performance on August 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Amritsar, dated August 17, 1964. The Subordinate Judge had decreed the plaintiffs suit for possession of the premises by specific performance of the agreement to sell.

facts.text: Agreement to sell concluded on December 9, 1959 between Dr. Jiwan Lal, Shri Krishan Das, Bal Kishan Das (predecessor of appellants 3-8), and Brij Mohan Mehra.

anchor.surface_text: Brij Mohan Mehra, one of the respondents, was the defendant, and the appellants were the plaintiffs in the suit. There was an agreement between Dr. Jiwan Lal, the first appellant, Shri Krishan Das the second appellant, and one Bal Kishan Das, the predecessor in interest of the appellants Nos. 3 to 8 and Brij Mohan Mehra.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Mehra agreed to sell premises to Dr. Jiwan Lal, Shri Krishan Das and Bal Kishan Das for Rs. 122500/- under the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It was companycluded on December 9, 1959. By that agreement Brij Mohan agreed to sell the premises in suit to Dr. Jiwan Lal, Shri Kishan Das and Bal Kishan Das. The sale companysideration was Rs. 122500/-

facts.text: Prospective vendees paid Rs. 10,000/- as earnest money on December 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The sale companysideration was Rs. 122500/-. The prospective vendees paid Rs. 10,000/- as earnest money. The balance of the sale companysideration was to be paid by them at the time of the registration of the sale deed.

facts.text: Sale deed to be executed within three months from date premises vacated by Income-tax Authorities and intimation given by registered post.

anchor.surface_text: The material terms incorporated in cls. 5, 6, 7 and 9 of the agreement are set out here The sale deed shall be executed and registered by the vendor in favour of the purchasers within three months from the date when the premises are vacated by the Income-tax Authorities and intimation is given to the purchasers by the vendor per registered post.

facts.text: Clause 6: If premises requisitioned by Government prior to registration, vendor to refund Rs. 10,000/- earnest money plus 6% interest per annum.

anchor.surface_text: In the event of the above said premises, which is the subject matter of sale number being vacated by the Income-tax Authorities or is subsequently requisitioned by the Government prior to the registration of the sale deed the vendor shall refund to the purchaser the sum of Rs. 10,000/-  Rupees ten thousand only  received by the vendor as earnest money plus interest at the rate of 6 per cent per annum.

facts.text: Premises requisitioned by Additional District Magistrate, Amritsar on January 23, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The premises were requisitioned by the Additional District Magistrate, Amritsar on January 23, 1960. Thereafter Brij Mohan Mehra refused to execute the sale-deed in spite of the requests of the prospective vendees.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Mehra refused to execute the sale deed after requisition despite requests.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Brij Mohan Mehra refused to execute the sale-deed in spite of the requests of the prospective vendees. So the plaintiffs instituted their suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit for specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: So the plaintiffs instituted their suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed premises requisitioned on manipulation of Brij Mohan Mehra.

anchor.surface_text: Their case was that the premises were requisitioned on the manipulation of Brij Mohan Mehra, that clause 6 of the agreement was intended to be for the benefit of the prospective vendees,

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed they waived condition in clause 6 and were ready and willing to perform.

anchor.surface_text: that the prospective vendees waived the companysideration in cl. 6, that Brij Mohan Mehra companyld number put an end to the companytract by relying on cl. 6, and that the plaintiffs have always been ready and willing to perform their part of the obligation under the agreement.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Mehra claimed agreement contingent and void on requisitioning.

anchor.surface_text: Brij Mohan Mehra companytested their claim. His case was that the agreement was a companytingent agreement, that it became void on the requisitioning of the premises,

facts.text: Brij Mohan Mehra denied manipulating requisition and claimed plaintiffs could not waive clause 6.

anchor.surface_text: that numbercontract ever came to existence prior to the requisitioning of the premises, that he did number manipulate for the requisition of the premises, that the plaintiffs companyld number waive the companydition in cl. 6,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held plaintiffs ready and willing, agreement not void, Brij manipulated requisition, could not rescind, plaintiffs waived cl.6, no laches.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that the plaintiffs were always ready and willing to perform their obligation under the agreement. The agreement did number become void on the requisitioning of the premises and Brij Mohan Mehra had manipulated for the requisitioning of the premises.

facts.text: High Court held clause 6 imposed obligations only if vacant possession, contract fell through on requisition, no waiver possible.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that cl. 6 of the agreement imposed obligations on Brij Mohan Mehra to sell and on the prospective vendees to buy only if vacant possession companyld be delivered to the latter and number otherwise.

facts.text: Suit instituted on November 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted on November 5, 1962.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Mehra appealed requisition order, dismissed on August 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Brij Mohan Mehra filed an appeal against the order of requisition. It was dismissed on August 1, 1960.

facts.text: Brij Mohan sent letter with cheque for Rs. 10,103.28 on February 11, 1960, interest calculated from December 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: When the premises were requisitioned he sent a letter on February 11, 1960 along with a cheque for Rs. 10,103.28 to the prospective vendees. In the letter he has expressly stated that the interest has been calculated from December 9, 1959 to, February 11, 1960.

facts.text: Prospective vendees sent notice on April 17, 1960 via Sardari Lal Sachdev to attend Sub-Registrar on April 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually on April 17, 1960 one Sardari Lal Sachdev, Advocate, gave numberice on behalf of the prospective vendees to Shri Hans Raj Mittal, Advocate, for Brij Mohan Mehra.

facts.text: Plaintiffs tendered Rs. 1,12,500/- before Sub-Registrar on April 30, 1960 (holiday), Brij Mohan did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: It is said in that numberice that the prospective vendees would attend the office of the Sub-Registrar, Amritsar on April 30, 1960 between 10 A.M. and 12 numbern and that Brij Mohan Mehra should reach there to get the sale deed registered.

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was a concluded contract from inception.

anchor.surface_text: Re. Point No. 1. Neither party has argued that there was numberformation of the companytract between the parties. The companytract was number made subject to the number-requisitioning of the premises.

facts.text: Supreme Court held non-requisitioning not condition precedent to seller's obligation to sell.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is numberhing in the agreement in general and in cl. 6 in particular to show that the, number-requisitioning of the premises was a companydition precedent to the performance of the sellers obligation to sell the premises,

facts.text: Supreme Court held non-requisitioning was condition precedent to buyers' obligation to buy, but waivable by buyers.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the number-requisitioning of the premises was a companydition precedent to the performance of. the buyers obligation to buy the premises. When the premises were requisitioned the buyers companyld rescind the companytract, if they so desired.

facts.text: Supreme Court held buyers could waive clause 6 as it was for their exclusive benefit.

anchor.surface_text: As already discussed, cl. 6 was inserted in the agreement for the, exclusive benefit of the vendees and number for the benefit of the vender as well as the vendees. So the vendees companyld waive the companydition precedent specified in el. 6.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no laches or abandonment by plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the plaintiffs did number abandon their rights under the agreement. The institution of the suit after two years does number appear to have caused any disadvantage to Brij Mohan Mehra.

facts.text: Supreme Court decreed suit, directed Brij Mohan to execute sale deed on payment of Rs. 112500/- within two months.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court. The suit of the plaintiffs is decreed. Brij Mohan Mehra is directed to execute a sale deed in favour of the plaintiffs in terms of the agreement, dated December 9, 1959,
The Subordinate Judge had decreed the plaintiffs suit for possession of the premises by specific performance of the agreement to sell. The High Court dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The institution of the suit after two years does not appear to have caused any disadvantage to Brij Mohan Mehra. As already stated earlier,

holdings.text: There was a concluded contract between the parties from the inception.

anchor.surface_text: Was there a concluded contract? Re. Point No. 1. Neither party has argued that there was no formation of the contract between the parties. The contract was not made subject to the non-requisitioning of the premises. By cl. 1 of the agreement, the vendor agreed to sell and the purchasers agreed to purchase the premises. Clause 5 makes the vendor liable to execute a sale deed within a certain time. So there was a concluded contract between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.1 creates vendor's obligation to sell and cl.5 timing; no argument against formation; not subject to non-requisitioning.

holdings.text: The non-requisitioning of the premises was not a condition precedent to the performance of the seller's obligation to sell the premises, nor did the contract come to an end on requisitioning.

anchor.surface_text: Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent to the performance of the sellers obligation to sell Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent ... In our view there is nothing in the agreement in general and in cl. 6 in particular to show that the, non-requisitioning of the premises was a condition precedent to the performance of the sellers obligation to sell the premises, or that the contract came to an end on the requisitioning of the premises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express words subjecting seller's duty to non-requisition; cl.6 refund obligation implies ongoing contract; conduct shows interest from agreement date; purposive reading favors seller not gaining from condition.

holdings.text: Interest on earnest money accrues from the date of the agreement (December 9, 1959), not from requisition.

anchor.surface_text: When the premises were requisitioned he sent a letter on February 11, 1960 along with a cheque for Rs. 10,103.28 to the prospective vendees. In the letter he has expressly stated that the interest has been calculated from December 9, 1959 to, February 11, 1960.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seller's conduct in calculating and tendering interest from agreement date confirms accrual from then.

holdings.text: The non-requisitioning of the premises was a condition precedent to the performance of the buyers' obligation to buy the premises; buyers could rescind upon requisition.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the non-requisitioning of the premises was a condition precedent to the performance of. the buyers obligation to buy the premises. When the premises were requisitioned the buyers could rescind the contract, if they so desired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Buyers sought vacant possession for hotel; cl.6 creates refund right implying rescission option; lawyer witness confirms vendees' interest.

holdings.text: Clause 6 was inserted for the exclusive benefit of the vendees, not the vendor.

anchor.surface_text: As already discussed, cl. 6 was inserted in the agreement for the, exclusive benefit of the vendees and not for the benefit of the vender as well as the vendees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object to protect vendees' desire for vacant possession; vendor gains nothing; no mutual benefit.

holdings.text: The vendees could unilaterally waive the condition precedent in clause 6.

anchor.surface_text: Could the buyers waive the condition and insist on the performance of the sellers obligation ? ... So the vendees could waive the condition precedent specified in cl. 6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Condition for exclusive benefit of one party waivable unilaterally; precedents (Dalsukh, Hawksley, Morrell) confirm.

holdings.text: The plaintiffs were ready and willing to perform their obligations.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually on April 17, 1960 one Sardari Lal Sachdev, Advocate, gave notice on behalf of the prospective vendees to Shri Hans Raj Mittal, ... Dr. Jiwan Lal, one of the plaintiffs, has deposed that even after April 29, 1960, he had been asking Brij Mohan Mehra to execute a registered

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence, notice, tender of Rs.112500 before Sub-Registrar, testimony of Dr. Jiwan Lal and Sub-Registrar.

holdings.text: The buyers were not guilty of laches and did not abandon their claim.

anchor.surface_text: Were the buyers guilty of laches and was there abandonment of their claim ? ... The suit cannot accordingly be, dismissed on account of delay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable delay awaiting appeal outcome; no prejudice to defendant (no allegation/evidence); continuous pursuit; Lindsay Petroleum on laches not arbitrary.

holdings.text: No need to decide if requisition was manipulated by defendant.

anchor.surface_text: In view of our earlier findings, it is not necessary to decide whether the requisitioning of the premises was a manoeuvre of Brij Mohan Mehra to slide back from the agreement.

holdings.text: Suit decreed for specific performance; High Court judgment set aside; defendant to execute sale deed on tender of Rs.112500 plus expenses.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court. The suit of the plaintiffs is decreed. Brij Mohan Mehra is directed to execute a sale deed in favour of the plaintiffs in terms of the agreement, dated December 9, 1959,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of findings on contract, conditions, waiver, readiness, no laches.

precedents.citation: Dalsukh M. Pancholi v. The Guarantee Life and Employment Insurance Co., Ltd. and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Dalsukh M. Pancholi v. The Guarantee Life and Employment Insurance Co., Ltd. and others 1 , there was an agreement for sale of immovable property. The property was under attachment by an order of the Court and was about to be sold by public auction. A certain amount was paid by the prospective vendee as earnest money. Clause 4 of the agreemen

precedents.case_name: Dalsukh M Pancholi v Guarantee Life and Employment Insurance Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: A condition precedent not exclusively for the benefit of the purchaser cannot be waived unilaterally by the purchaser
precedents.cited_holding: as the condition in cl. 4 was not exclusively for the benefit of the purchaser it could not be waived by him and that the entire contract fell through

anchor.surface_text: It would follow that where a stipulation is for the exclusive benefit of one contracting party and does not create liabilities against him he can waive it unilaterally. See also Hawksley v. Outram 2 and Morrell v. Studd and Millington 3 Re. Point No. 5 The agreem

precedents.cited_proposition: A party can unilaterally waive a stipulation inserted exclusively for its benefit

anchor.surface_text: of the contract. In Iindsay Petroleum Co. v. Hurd 4 , Lord Selborne said The doctrine of laches in courts of equity is not an arbitrary or technical doctrine. Where it would be practically unjust to give a remedy either because the party has by his conduct done that which might fairly be regarded as an equivalent to a waiver of it, or where by his conduct

precedents.cited_proposition: The doctrine of laches in courts of equity is not an arbitrary or technical doctrine
precedents.cited_holding: Where it would be practically unjust to give a remedy either because the party has by his conduct done that which might fairly be regarded as an equivalent to a waiver of it, or where by his conduct and neglect he has... put the other party in a situation in which it would not be reasonable to place him if the remedy were afterwards to be asserted, in either of these cases lapse of time and delay are most material

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court. The suit of the plaintiffs is decreed. Brij Mohan Mehra is directed to execute a sale deed in favour of the plaintiffs in terms of the agreement, dated December 9, 1959, on the plaintiffs tendering to him a sum of Rs. 112500/- and necessary expenses for execution and registration of the sale deed within two months from today.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment and decree set aside; plaintiffs' suit decreed; specific performance directed by execution of sale deed upon tender of balance sale consideration.
directions: Brij Mohan Mehra directed to execute sale deed in favour of plaintiffs in terms of agreement dated December 9, 1959, within two months on tender of Rs. 112500/- and expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Was there a concluded contract? Re. Point No. 1. Neither party has argued that there was no formation of the contract between the parties. The contract was not made subject to the non-requisitioning of the premises. By cl. 1 of the agreement, the vendor agreed to sell and the purchasers agreed to purchase the premises. Clause 5 makes the vendor liable to execute a sale deed within a certain time. So there was a concluded contract between the parties.

We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court. The suit of the plaintiffs is decreed. Brij Mohan Mehra is directed to execute a sale deed in favour of the plaintiffs in terms of the agreement, dated December 9, 1959, on the plaintiffs tendering to him a sum of Rs. 112500/- and necessary expenses for execution and registration of the sale deed within two months from today.

We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court. The suit of the plaintiffs is decreed. Brij Mohan Mehra is directed to execute a sale deed in favour of the plaintiffs in terms of the agreement, dated December 9, 1959, on the plaintiffs tendering to him a sum of Rs. 112500/- and necessary expenses for execution and registration of the sale deed within two months from today.

anchor.surface_text: Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent to the performance of the sellers obligation to sell Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent ... In our view there is nothing in the agreement in general and in cl. 6 in particular to show that the, non-requisitioning of the premises was a condition precedent to the performance of the sellers obligation to sell the premises, or that the contract came to an end on the requisitioning of the premises.
